title: Good feed with good service
text: On our recent trip to Quilpie we enjoyed a great meal at the Hotel Imperial Restaurant. My son had a chicken parmigiama that was simply massive and I had a 400g steak which was as big as the plate. Well recommended

title: Very Comfortable Stay in the Outback
text: After a long 11hr drive from Brisbane, the Channel Country Tourist Park was a delight with a very easy check in process and extremely comfortable cabin. The cabin was perfectly setup with a very comfortable Queen sized bed, stove top and microwave. Well worth a stay whilst in Quilpie

title: Private Cabin is well worth the stay
text: My son and I recently stayed at the Artesian Waters Caravan Park on a recent trip to Yowah. The private cabin had a great setup with a really comfortable bed, good bathroom, a very large outdoor bath fed by the warm artesian bore and a private BBQ. It was a great cabin to come back to after a day of fossicking in the opal fields.

title: Great Apartment in the City Centre
text: Cairns City Apartments comprise 3 apartment blocks in the center of Cairns right opposite to Cairns Central Shopping Centre and an easy 10 min to the waterfront and marina for cruise departures to the Great Barrier Reef. Our family of 5 stayed in the 3 Bedroom apartment in the Claredon on Spence. The apartment itself was well equipped with a very spacious lounge room and probably the largest outside deck/courtyard area I have ever seen in any apartment. Anna the manager was extremely accommodating and even though the office was shut on a Saturday afternoon met us the moment we called her to say we had arrived. Highly recommended

title: Fantastic Private Tour of Gallipoli
text: My family and I choose to do a private day tour of Gallipoli through Gallipoli Tour (tour run by Crowded House) and were not disappointed. We were picked up in a VW private van from the old town at 7:30am in the morning and enjoyed a pleasant drive down to the Gallipoli peninsula. When we arrived we we met our tour guide Hussein and were taken to great local restaurant for lunch. From there Hussein proceeded to guide us around the main sites of Gallipoli, taking time to answer my kids endless questions and also allowing us plenty of time to explore each site and memorial. Finally we finished up the tour a little bit early and our driver had us back in Istanbul by 8:30pm. A great way to experience Gallipoli and a fabulous side trip from Istanbul

title: Great Location and Good Food
text: Kybele Restaurant is an enjoyable restaurant located near to the Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque.The food is authentic and there is a good selection, the service prompt and the atmosphere is really enjoyable.

title: Authentic Turkish and International Cuisine
text: Albura Kathisma is wonderful restaurant located in the Sultanahmet district of Istanbul. They offer a very wide menu of both traditional Turkish and International Cuisine. The service is absolutely wonderful and the food is some of the best around. I had the Traditional Chicken cooked in Terracotta whilst my wife had a Spinach Crepe. My kids also enjoyed the kids menu. We also tried the desserts and I found the Traditional Turkish Rice Pudding which was absolutely divine.

title: Fantastic Restaurant
text: Wonderful restaurant located in the Fatih area of the Sultanahmet District very near the Blue Mosque. The food is absolutely delicious and the service was wonderful. We were offered complimentary Apple Tea and bread with our meals.

title: Great Authentic Restaurant the is Reasonably Priced
text: We dined here one night whilst staying around the corner at the Ferman Konak Hotel. The service was excellent and the food even better. My kids especially loved the Turkish Pides whilst my wife and I enjoyed their great kebaps.

title: Triumph of Roman Engineering
text: The Valens Aqueduct is a wonderful reminder of how great Constantinople was at its peak. Built in the 4th Century AD, the aqueduct was maintained by both the Byzantine and Ottoman empires meaning that it has been well preserved over the Millennia and remains so today. For those interested in Roman history it is well worth a visit.

title: Historic Shopping Street in the Beyoglu Area of Istanbul
text: Istiklal Street is the prime shopping street of Istanbul and is full of charm an character. It is worth working the length of the street from Taskim Square down to the Bosphorus. It is fantastic to see the historic trams pushing their way through the crowds. It is also worth stopping for an ice-cream from one of the many vendors on the side of the street as this is quite an experience in itself!

title: Original Souk and Undercover Shopping Area
text: The Grand Bazaar is an institution and one of the absolute highlights of any visit to Istanbul. It truly is a maze of shops and small streets and alleyways where you can buy everything from musical instruments, to lamps, tiles, clothing, carpets and heaps of Turkish Delights and nuts. To really appreciate it, allow at least 2<3hrs!

title: Wonderful Mosque but is currently undergoing major renovation
text: I have been fortunate enough to visit the Blue Mosque a number of times and it is certainly one of the most significant and beautiful mosques in Istanbul. Built in 1609, the Blue Mosque is unique in the fact that it is one of the two mosques in Turkey that has six minarets (only the great mosque in Mecca has more). Whilst it is still worth a visit, it is worth noting that at present the Mosque is undergoing the final stages of major restoration, so you cannot view the dome and a lot of the tiling internally at the moment.

title: Wonderful Water Storage Facility of a Bi-gone Era
text: Built by Justinian in 3rd Century AD, the Basilica Cistern is a magnificent water storage facility located beneath the Sultanate are of Istanbul. Besides the sheer beauty of the open cavern, the beautiful columns and the carved medusa's head is worth seeing. Be aware that there is always a line, though it moves quickly, and it can get crowded with tour groups! This aside, it is well worth a visit!

title: Centre of the Ottoman Empire
text: Topkapi Palace is a sprawling palace which was the heart of the Ottoman Empire for the Mehmed's conquests up to the middle of the 18th century. The building is well preserved and has a lot to offer the visitor from the 4 courtyards to the Harem and the Circumcision Room. The collection of clothing and weaponry of the Sultans as well as relics and the scientific artefacts make visiting the palace even more of a must for anyone visiting Istanbul

title: Magnificent Genoese Tower that is a Key Landmark in Istanbul
text: Galata Tower is a 9 story tower built in 1348 and when it was completed was the highest landmark in the city. During the Ottoman Period it was used as an observation tower for spotting fires. It is worth being aware that the queues to visit are quite long as only a set number of people can fit on the balcony which surrounds the tower. My family and I visited in the late afternoon just before sunset and were rewarded with a beautiful view over the Bosphorus as the sunset over the famous monuments. Well worth taking the time to visit or even stopping at the restaurant/cafe at the top for a meal with a view!

title: Finest Mosque in Istanbul
text: The Suleymaniye Mosque commissioned by Suleiman the Magnificent and build by the imperial architect Mimar Sinan between 1550 and 1557 is amongst the finest Mosques found anywhere in the world. From the courtyards and grounds that surround the mosque to the intricate tiling of the interior, it is simply stunning. The dome is the 2nd largest in Istanbul after the Hagia Sophia and is an absolute wonder as is the Mausoleums. My son and I visited in the mid-afternoon after midday prayers and the mosque was relatively quiet. Unfortunately the Mausoleum of Suleiman was closed but we were able to visit Roxelana's which was beautiful.

title: Truly Magnificent
text:
The Hagia Sophia is one of the most significant buildings in world and an absolute architectural marvel. Built in 360 AD, it served as an Eastern Orthodox Cathedral at the height of the late Eastern Roman/Byzantine Empire, was turned into a Catholic Church during the 4th Crusade before being converted into a mosque after the Ottoman conquest on Constantinople and finally in 1931 was turned into a museum by Ataturk. The dome was the largest in the world for almost 1,000 years and served as an inspiration to both Christian and Islamic architecture that followed. Elements of the history of the Hagia Sophia can be viewed today from the beautiful Byzantine mosaics through to the mihrab, minarets and beautiful calligraphy on the dome that marks its time as a mosque. The building is highly accessible with ramps instead of stairs up to the 2nd level gallery (note that they can be somewhat slippery). It is worth also having a pre-purchased ticket in order to skip the permanently present queue. A must whilst in Istanbul

Whilst

title: Great Honey Puffs
text: I took my family here looking for a place that served authentic Honey Puffs and was not disappointed. We had some of the traditional as well as some with Pistachio and these were devince. Located on the Aiolou and Aghias Irinis Street in the Plaka the shop is easy to find and well worth the visit

title: Wonderful Old Church Located on Philopappos Hill
text: The Church of Saint Demetrios Loumbardiaris is located very near to the Acropolis at the foot of Philopappas Hill. It s Byzantium in origin it is quite unique in it design. Unfortunately when I visited it was closed, but looking through the windows the mosaics inside look absolutely fantastic, Well worth stopping by if you are looking for something else to do in Athens

title: Interesting Ruin
text: As the name suggests, Hadrian's Library is the ruins of the great library created by the Emperor Hadrian in Athens in AD132. Included as part of the Combo Ticket, if you have time it is worth a visit if just to get a sense of how big it actually was, even though the main thing remaining is the columns. One thing that is worth seeing is the statue of Nike which is in a small building on one side of the site.

title: Roman Monument in the Centre of Athens
text: Hadrians Arch is a well preserved monument in central Athens. It differs in design considerably to the typical triumphal arches seen elsewhere and from that perspective alone is well worth visiting. It is also free to visit and very near to other monuments including the Temple of Olympian Zeus.

title: Worth Seeing Just for the Tower of the Winds
text: The Roman Agora, located near Monastiraki is a collection of monuments and buildings dating from the Roman occupation of Athens in the early 1st Century AD. It is another ancient site included on the combined ticket and is worth visiting just for the Tower of the Winds which is a water clock from Roman Times.

title: Fascinating Museum Highlighting Ancient Greek Technology
text: The museum is located in 2 parts with the building on Apostolou Pavlou street focusing on the technology of war in ancient Greece whilst the other building on Iraklidon street is focused on other innovations including early robotics "AUTOMATONS" from the 3rd Century BC

title: One of the Best Byzantine Churches in Athens
text: Thought to be built in the 11th Century, the Church of Kapnikarea is one of the finest examples of Byzantine architecture in Athens. The church is located on Ermou street in the heart of the Plaka. Worth taking the time to stop and visit

title: Birthplace of the Modern Olympics
text: Originally built in 330 BC, the Panathenaic Stadium was one of the key sites for both the first of the Modern Olympics in 1896 and the 2004 Olympic Opening and Closing ceremonies as well as several events. Whilst the stadium was restored over the millennia, the original marble is still absolutely beautiful to behold (the Panathenaic Stadium is the only stadium in the world built completely of marble). My kids enjoyed running around the track and standing on the podium. Well worth a visit!

title: Centre of the Ancient Greek World
text: The Ancient Agora is a vast site located near the Plaka and Acropolis in Athens. It was the centre of the ancient Greek world and the home of democracy. We visited late in the day and there was hardly any crowds around on site. Some of the highlights include the Odeon of Agrippa, Strategeion, Monument of the Eponymous Heroes, and Temple of Hephaestus. The museum has an interesting collection of objects found at the site.

title: Free Historic Site
text: Philopappos Hill is a magnificent, expansive and free site in the heart of Athens that is home to a number of key monuments including the Pnyx (meeting place of the popular assemblys in ancient Athens), Philopappu Monument, Socrates Prison etc. The site is quite extensive so allow plenty of time to look around. It is also the place to come if you want a unique view of the Acropolis

title: One of the Best Museums in the World
text: Absolutely spectacular museum which traces the history of Greece from the earliest Cycladic, Mineon and Myceraean Greece through the Classical Period right up to the end of Roman Occupation. Many of the greatest treasures of Greece are here including the Mask of Agamemnon, Antikythera Mechanism, Artemision Bronze of either Zeus or Poseidon, Antikythera Ephebe and Aphrodite,Pan and Eros. To top this all off, the frescos and finds of Akrotiri are here! Finally the current display on The countless aspects of Beauty is simply stunning and is worth rushing to see before it closes at the end of December. A must for everyone visiting Athens

title: Most Complete Ancient Temple in Athens
text: The Temple of Hephaestus is a doric peripteral temple located in the Ancient Agora and is truly one of the greatest sites from the Classical Greek period. Construction on the temple was built by 449BC and it took 30 years to complete. Around 700 AD it became a Church of St George and thus was preserved as thus until the mid 1800s when King Otto turned it into a museum before it reverted back to being purely Athens most preserved temple in the 1930s. The Temple of Hephaestus is truly a great monument which is the highlight of a visit to the Agora.

title: Heart of Athens
text: The Plaka is the historic shopping district at the heart of Athens. There is a real mixture of shops from the atypical souvenir shops through to a range of high end retailers. The market is especially interesting

title: Simple Magnificence
text: The Acropolis is located in the heart of Athens and been the centre of Athenian life for more than 2,500 years. The site is so much more than just the Pantheon and includes the Parthenon, the Propylaia, the Erechtheion and the Temple of Athena Nike. On the slopes of the Acropolis you will also find the Theatre of Dionysus and the Odeon of Herodes Atticus. If you see nothing else in Athens, make sure you visit the Acropolis!

title: Icon of the Ancient World
text: The Parthenon is probably the greatest wonder of the ancient world and Athens' greatest treasure. The site itself is absolutely amazing and the Greek government has done a wonderful job over the last 20 years or so preserving and restoring the site. We visited early in the morning at opening time to beat the crowds and had pre-purchased our tickets in advance as part of the 5 ancient sites from the Ministry of Culture so was able to skip the line and climb right up (my children were free as well!). It is a short climb up the stairs to get to the top of the Acropolis itself, but it is well worth it!

title: Magnificent Museum Focused on the History of the Acropolis
text: The 'new' acropolis museum is simply wonderful and one of best dedicated museums in the world. There is a huge number of artefacts that have been collected from the acropolis. The top level is dedicated to the freeze (some of which has been reconstructed as much of the original is still in the British Museum) is brilliant. Finally the recently opened archaeological excavations beneath the museum give a real insight into how Athens looked in ancient times. Well worth a visit!

title: Good Food in a Great Setting
text: We visited this restaurant on our private tour of the island and were not disappointed. We were seated right on the beach, the service was prompt and food was really good. I had the octopus salad whilst the rest of my family had a chicken kebabs. Prices were reasonable

title: Fantastic restaurant in Oia
text: Whilst Roku is not renowned for its views all the locals rave about its authentic dishes and this is what attracted us to stop for dinner her. We were absolutely blown away by the food, wine and authentic friendly service!

title: One of the Most Important Archaeological Sites in the Ancient World
text: Akrotiri is one of the most significant archaeological sites in Greece and even in the ancient world. The site has been painstakingly excavated and the level of preservation is amazing for a place which is more than 4,000 years old. It is fantastic that the site has been completely enclosed under an expansive roof to protect the site from the weather. Whilst you can do a guided tour with some of the archaeologists if you choose, the site is well signposted with explanation videos in a couple of sections.

title: Unique volcanic beach
text: Perissa is a beautiful beach in Santorini covered in black volcanic sand. Plenty of restaurants and bars line the beachfront and many provide deck chairs and pavilions for sunbathing on the sand. Unique part of Santorini

title: Wonderful Experience
text: We were lucky enough to be staying in one of the apartments built into the cliff on Oia overlooking the Caldera and from our balcony were able to watch the sunset over the beautiful domes of the churches. It was simply breathtaking and something not to miss. For those people who were not luck enough to stay in Oia, if you want to view the sunset from the old castle, you need to arrive a good 60 to 90 minutes before the sunset as it was rather crowded on the narrow streets of Oia - even in October and with only 2 moderate cruise ships visiting Santorini.

title: Simply the Best Private Tour Ever
text: Santorini Road Trips is simply one of the absolute best private tour companies anywhere in the world. We booked the private tour as our family of 5 (2 adults, a 13 yr old, 11yr old and 9yr) only was spending 2 days on Santorini and wanted to make the best of it! We had a few specific requests of what we wanted to see such as seeing the Firostefani blue domed church, traditional villages, a Family wine farm for local wine and handmade products tasting, Red beach, Archaeological site of Akrotiri and George was able to suggest an itinerary to suit. The tour itself was absolutely wonderful! Nikolas our driver and guide was simply fantastic - providing so much knowledge around everything to do with the island, showing us the hidden spots that tourists don't usually go to, teaching my kids about the local geography and also plants including the way vines are grown for wine making, native capers and figs etc. He also took the best family photos we had on our 6 week trip to Europe!!! Simply marvellous all round!
place: Private Classic Santorini Panorama: Visit the most popular destinations!

title: Most Beautiful Traditional Village in Santorini
text: Megalochori is one of the few un-spoilt traditional villages in Santorini and is a place where you can experience what Santorini used to be like. Traffic is not allowed in the centre of town and as a result you can wonder the little cobble streets, explore the original cave houses, visit the cafes and taverns in the central town square and see the churches at your leisure.

title: Wonderful Bay and a True Gem of Santorini
text: Amoudi Bay, located just below Oia, is a wonderful part of Santorini. The bay itself has crystal clear water and if you are brave enough to venture around the headland you are rewarded with a wonderful gem of a swimming spot. The walk down from Oia (and more to the point back up...yes there is around 250 wide and somewhat well warn steps) is quite steep - but you can take a taxi as alternative. The seafood restaurants with the octopus drying out the front are iconic, as is the red cliffs looking back up to Oia is something else. Well worth the visit when in Santorini!

title: Wonderful Art Gallery and Winery
text: Art Space is a wonderful Art Gallery and winery built into caves in Exo Gonia. The winery itself has been in the since Argiros family since 1861. The chambers of the old winery are built into pumice have been restored and used as a museum which provides the visitor with insights into the history of both the family and their wines. The family also produces rakidio as well as beautiful wines including Vinsanto which is a beautiful desert wine. The Art itself which adorns the walls of the old winery caves is simply exquisite

title: One of the Best Archaeological Sites in the World
text: Pompeii is simply one of the finest Roman ruins in the world. The main site is absolutely immense in size and to see it properly you should allow at least 5<6hrs. Some of the key attractions include: the Temple of Apollo, Lupanar, House of Faun, Amphitheatre, Teatro Grande, Teatro Piccolo etc. Due to the size of the site, it pays to work out the attractions you want to see before you arrive and plan your visit around these. My teenage sons and I made a day trip from Rome which was easy enough though we almost missed the train back due to the very late operation of the local Circumvesuviana train.

title: Small Museum Hosing the Ara Pacis
text: The Ara Pacis was an alter commissioned by Augustus to commemorate the Roman Peace. It is an absolutely fantastic monument with wonderful reliefs including one which features the Imperial Family - Augustus, Agrippa, Julia, Octavia Minor, and Tiberius. The new museum is also a wonderful way to protect this important monument and well worth a visit.

title: One of the Finest Museum/Art Galleries in the World
text: The Vatican Museum houses one of the single greatest collections of any museum or art gallery in the world. The museum is divided into different sub-museums covering named after the Pope who created them covering human history from the ancient Egyptians, Greeks and Romans right up to the modern day. There are just too many master pieces to list here, but this museum is so much more than just the Sistine Chapel. Some of the must sees include Stanze di Raffaello (Raphael's rooms), Rodin's the thinker, Bellini's Pieta, Caravaggio's Entombment, the Egyptian mummies, the gallery of maps and so on. There are a few things to note - definitely pre-purchase your ticket to skip the line as the queues are horrendous if you do not. The halls that make up the museum are not that wide and with the very high number of tour groups even before 9am in the morning can make seeing things difficult. Study the map of the museum and have a plan before you go! With 20,000+ artefacts and paintings on display, it is easy to miss something. An absolute must - at least once in a lifetime

title: Trajan's Triumphal Column
text: One of the most impressive and best preserve monuments from ancient, Trajan's Triumphal Coumn celebrates his victories over the Dacians. It possible is one of the earliest form of propaganda, but is still is impressive and the detail of the relief's on the column is something to behold!

title: Beautiful Attraction Built to Commemorate Italy's First King
text: Altare Della Patria is a magnificent building built to commemorate the unification of Italy and Italy's first king Victor Emmanual II. It also houses the tomb of the unknown soldier. Worth a visit!

title: Michelangelo's Masterpiece
text: The Sistine Chapel is one of those 'once-in-a-lifetime' experiences that every traveller should try and do. Since its restoration and cleaning, the colours of ceiling have become so much more vibrant and it is a true masterpiece. When we visited it was quite crowded and it is worth noting that photos of any type are not allowed.

title: Beautiful Staircase, But Always Crowded
text: The Spanish Steps is one of "the" attactions to visit in Rome. Whilst it is nice and located in the centre of Rome's main shopping district, unless you go early in the morning, crowds tends to somewhat spoil the experience and there really is not much to see.

title: Wonderful Attraction Worth Visiting First Before Other Attractions
text: Welcome to Rome is a recent attraction which outlines the development of Rome from its foundation to modern times. There are 5 different parts to the attraction, the large 3D theatre which main show which lasts 30 min as well as 4 smaller rooms focusing on a particular landmark - St Peter's; Forum; Castel Sant'Angelo. The technology used is impressive and for someone who has tweens and teens, it was well worth visiting Welcome to Rome first before visiting the landmarks as they have a better appreciation and were more engaged. Well done to the creative team behind the attraction!

title: Must See When in Rome
text: The Trevi Fountain is simply one of the most beautiful fountain in the world and a masterpiece of Baroque architecture. When we visited it was quite crowded, so if you want to avoid the crowds come early or late in the day

title: One of the Best Examples of Baroque Architecture
text: Piazza Navona is a true master piece of the Renaissance with some of the best Baroque Architecture found anywhere in Rome. The Piazza was built on Domitian's circus with the shape still very visible and is one of the largest open spaces in central Rome. The Fountain of the 4 rivers is particularly spectacular and in many ways as beautiful as the Trevi Fountain and quite unique with the Obelisk of Domitian on top of it. Well worth a visit and is located quite close the Pantheon and Trevi Fountain.

title: Heart of the Roman Republic and Empire
text: The Roman Forum is a fascinating area at the heart of the political and social centre of the both the Roman Republic and Empire. Whilst in ruins, there is so much to see and it is worth viewing it with either a guide or a good map to know what you are looking at!

title: Greatest of all Roman Monuments
text: Simply one of the most magnificent monuments of Rome which has stood for almost 2 Millennia. The Pantheon was the blueprint for all other domed churches and is an architectural marvel, especially considering the dome is non reinforced concrete. The best part is that it is free to visit and the queue to get in moves quite quickly!

title: Might and Magnificence of Rome
text: Despite being ravaged by barbarians, later civilisations and earthquakes, the Colossum remains one of the greatest of all Roman monuments and an absolutely quintessential attraction to visit when in Rome. It is well worth getting a skip the line ticket, especially if you want to visit around lunch time- but you need to do this at least a couple of months ahead of your visit as there are only limited tickets available at each time slot throughout the day! We took a private walking tour which was fantastic.

title: Medieval Tower in need of restoration
text: Torre Guelfa was once part of the town walls in Pisa. Whilst it is quite interesting to look at and still worth a look, but be warned, the site is a bit of a shambles and is currently not open to visitors.

title: Charming historic square
text: The Knight's Square is the traditional political heart of Pisa where the Knights of St Stephen had their head quarters. Cosimo de Medici built St Stephen's church which is located on the square and this is well worth visiting.

title: Worth taking the time to visit when visiting the Leaning Tower
text: The Duomo is quite a magnificent building and worth taking the time to view when visiting the Leaning Tower. Entry is free if you are visiting one of the other museums or buildings onsite. This particular duomo is older than Florences and very different in design so well worth a visit just to compare the 2 and also to view the beautiful artwork

title: Beautiful little church, shame it wasn't open
text: We visited Pisa on a Thursday and discovered this charming little church right on the banks for the Arno. It is an incredibly beautiful church from the outside so I was really hoping that we could see inside - alas it was closed both when we walked past on the way to the Duomo/Learning Tower about 10am and still closed when we came back past a 1pm in the afternoon.
place: Chiesa di Santa Maria della Spina
